ASIA-PAC

Senior White House Official stated that a US-China deal is almost there, but discussions continue on tech transfer and IP protections alongside performance mechanisms, according to Politico's Morning Money. (Politico)

China said that its President Xi and US President Trump are in continuous contact as the sides work out a trade deal, while other reports stated that China is pressing US President Trump to remove more tariffs ahead of the trade deal signing. Furthermore, China is said to be open to various options of where to sign a trade deal with the US but will be careful to avoid giving too many concessions according to sources. (Newswires/Xinhua/SCMP)

China President Xi met with Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam on Monday and said he appreciated her as well as her team's hard work during months of social unrest, while he reiterated the central government’s trust in Hong Kong government. (Global Times)

UK Brexit Party Leader Farage said he has given up on attempting to form a leave alliance with the Conservative Party and will move ahead with plan to contest over 600 seats. (Times)

Three pro-EU British political parties, the Liberal Democrats, Plaid Cymru and Green party along with some independent MPs, hope to unveil a Remain election pact as early as Thursday. There were also reports that Northern Ireland's pro-EU nationalist parties have agreed to stand back from three parliament seats to support the chance of anti-Brexit candidates. (FT)

US

Fed's Kashkari (2020 voter, Dove) said balance of risks are tilted to the downside and repeated the argument that monetary policy has been too tight during the recovery. Kashkari is concerned about trend of inflation expectations and suggested forward guidance can play role in helping, while he does not want to rule out negative rates in the future but noted it is not his forecast. (Newswires)

US Factory Orders (Sep) M/M -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

The week got off on the front-foot for markets, with gratitude to the usually reserved US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, who projected a November timeline for the Phase 1 deal, a Huawei waiver announcement due soon (seeing a bid in Huawei US-listed suppliers) and that the US may not need to slap auto tariffs on the EU. There were also constructive comments out of Chinese publications which saw new ATHs in the SPX (resistance at 3085), bear steepening in the Treasury curve, assisting the greenback whilst bullion prices edged lower (yet remaining above 1,500) and helping the crude benchmarks get off on the front foot as they threat the top end of their multi-week ranges. Sprint (S) traded ~1% lower after it reported a loss per share of USD 0.07, deeper than the street consensus for a loss of USD 0.02. Revenue also fell short, printing USD 7.8bln (Exp. 8.17bln). It also noted it expects the deal with T-Mobile (TMUS) to close in early 2020, who also traded lower on Monday. Bausch Health (BHC) traded higher on revenue beats and an increase in its FY revenue view, albeit in line with expectations. Sysco (SYY) traded marginally lower; EPS beat expectations by USD 0.02 and revenue’s missed by USD 200mln. Under Armour (UAA) also reported figures although it was largely overlooked given the recent federal investigation into the company. Nonetheless, it reported EPS beats and revenue came in line with street estimates. S&P 500 0.4% at 3078, NASDAQ-100 0.6% at 8211, Dow Jones 0.4% at 27463.

The TPLEX bear steepened on Monday following the positive risk sentiment, in addition to a stronger dollar and a large slate of issuance seeing investors pare back their debt holdings. US Commerce Secretary Ross gave promising comments on the US-China and EU auto-tariff fronts, reducing haven demand. Additionally, participants are facing a large amount of debt issuance, both from corporates and sovereigns, with the Treasury refunding auctions in the 3-year, 10-year and 30-year scheduled this week, and the ramp-up in corporate supply, where ten IG issuers came to the dollar market on Monday. Treasuries headed lower throughout the day, catching steam from some block sales - 20k in the TYZ9 and 8k in the USZ9 – and by settlement yields were approximately 6bps higher at the long end, with the 2-year higher by just half of that. T-note futures (Z9) settled 14 ticks lower at 129-18+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 4th November 2019: Progressive China and EU rumblings see new market highs to start the week
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 4th November 2019: Progressive China and EU rumblings see new market highs to start the week

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude up

* REAR VIEW: Ross positive on China, EU & Huawei, China commentary also positive although more nuanced; Treasury imposes fresh Iran sanctions amid a perceived rising threat; large scale of IG issuance ahead of treasury refunding this week

* COMING-UP: Data: China Caixin Services PMI, UK Markit Services PMI, EZ Producer Prices, US International Trade, Markit Services and Composite PMI, ISM Non-manufacturing PMI and Business Activity, JOLTS Job Openings. Speakers: ECB’s Villeroy, Fed’s Barkin, Kaplan, Kashkari. Events: RBA Rate Decision. Supply: UK & US. Earnings: Allergan, Microchip Technology, Newmont Goldcorp, Regeneron, Associated British Foods, Imperial Brands, Telefonica, Pandora.

 

* US MARKET WRAP: The week got off on the front-foot for markets, with gratitude to the usually reserved US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, who projected a November timeline for the Phase 1 deal, a Huawei waiver announcement due soon (seeing a bid in Huawei US-listed suppliers) and that the US may not need to slap auto tariffs on the EU. There were also constructive comments out of Chinese publications which saw new ATHs in the SPX (resistance at 3085), bear steepening in the Treasury curve, assisting the greenback whilst bullion prices edged lower (yet remaining above 1,500) and helping the crude benchmarks get off on the front foot as they threat the top end of their multi-week ranges.

* US/CHINA TRADE WAR: Weekend commentary has been constructive. China on Friday said there was a "consensus in principle," and after the APEC meeting in mid-November was cancelled (where Presidents Trump and Xi were to sign the much anticipated Phase One part of the trade deal), officials seem to be making progress to find an alternative venue for the confab between the two leaders, with some suggestion that the meeting could take place in Iowa; Trump late Friday said both sides were discussing locations, "but I like to get deals done first." Reuters reported that it was not immediately clear whether China would agree to sign the trade deal in the US. In another sign of apparent movement, on Sunday US Commerce Secretary Ross said licenses for US companies to sell components to China’s Huawei will come "very shortly," and added that there was no reason a trade deal could not be on track to be signed in November. On the location, SCMP reported China is open to various options of where to sign a trade deal with the US, but it will be careful to avoid giving too many concessions, according to sources.

* US/EU TRADE WAR: The constructive trade narrative was buttressed further on news that the US sees no need to slap tariffs on EU autos by 14 November deadline.

* FED SPEAKERS: Fed's Kashkari, a dove who will vote on monetary policy in 2020, said the balance of risks are were still tilted to the downside, and repeated his argument that monpol has been too tight during recovery. Kashkari said he was concerned about the trend in inflation expectations and repeated his view that forward guidance might play role in helping. On future policy, Kashkari said that negative rates cannot be ruled out as a tool. On potential future moves, Kashkari seemed to indicate he was data dependent, and also noted that the Fed does not know where neutral rate exactly is, but Kashkari thinks rates are around neutral and somewhat accommodative. Elsewhere, he observed that wage growth net of inflation was now positive, which is a very positive thing. Aftermarket, traders will be keeping an ear out for remarks by non-voter Daly.

* PBOC: China's central bank will on 5th November conduct MLF operations; key will be whether the PBOC rolls the CNY 403.5bln that matures, and whether it lowers the rate of its operation. UBS thinks it is highly likely that it rolls over the maturing MLFs, however, and the chance of an MLF rate cut is low it says. "While monetary policy can aid economic growth via lowering borrowing costs, if the lower interest rate cannot be effectively passed to the real economy, it doesn’t make much sense for the PBOC to lower the MLF rate too fast or too aggressively," UBS explains, "maybe that's why PBOC has recently switched to a less dovish tone even though the Chinese economy remains under substantial downward pressure," adding that transmission effectiveness might be a key concern for policymakers before they decide to ease further.

* GEOPOLITICS (IR/TU/NK): Iran’s Energy Authority announced the operation of 30 new centrifuges is now underway, adding they were driven to take these steps by Washington’s wrong policies, whilst they never intended to go ahead with it. This was later followed by the US imposing fresh Iranian sanctions on nine individuals and one entity related to Iran. In Turkey, the head of the defence industry announced the second delivery of the Russian S-400 missile system is planned for 2020 but could be delayed due to technology sharing and production talks, a move likely to raise concern in the US. Since the US removed the country from its F-35 programme, it announced it is now evaluating a Russian offer for fighter jets. Middle Eastern later reported that President Erdogan’s trip to the US is still not certain as it evaluates the pros and cons, adding “we should all understand that this was an invitation extended by Trump.  Turkey didn’t ask for a visit”. Over in North Korea, Yonhap reported working level talks with the US could take place in mid-November or December.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.4% at 3078, NASDAQ-100 0.6% at 8211, Dow Jones 0.4% at 27463.

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.1%, Consumer Staples -0.9%, Energy 3.2%, Financials 0.9%, Health Care -0.3%, Industrials 1.2%, Information Technology 0.6%, Materials 0.8%, Telecommunication Services 0.4%, Utilities -1.3%.

* STOCK SPECIFCS: Huawei suppliers (MU, WDC) caught a bid as US Commerce Secretary ross announced licenses for US companies to sell to Huawei will be coming shortly. McDonald’s (MCD) traded in the red following the removal of its CEO after he was involved in a consensual relationship with an employee, which the board deemed to violate company policy and demonstrated poor judgement. Its McDonald’s USA President became the successor immediately. Under Armour (UAA) an underperformer today as it is being investigated by Federal authorities over its accounting practices, in a probe which is examining whether the UAA shifted sales from quarter to quarter to seem healthier, according to WSJ citing people familiar with the matter; UAA announced it is cooperating with authorities. Uber (UBER) had its lawsuit dismissed by a Manhattan judge which challenged a NYC law which limits the number of licenses for ride-hailing services. Homebuilders (KBH, PHM, TOL, LEN) traded lower after PHM and KBH were downgraded to neutral from buy at Seaport Global, also a rise in treasury yields could also be a factor. Boeing (BA) traded higher despite source reports from NYT that the analysis of its 737 MAX jet led to a precautionary investigation of its 737 NG jet from the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) and the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).

* M&A: Stryker (SYK) traded in the red today as it announced it is to acquire Wright Medical (WMGI) for USD 30.75/shr, valued at USD 4.1bln. The announcement followed reports from over the weekend that WMGI hired advisors for a sale, where it stated SYK, Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Smith and Nephew (SNN) were potential suitors. Google's (GOOG) plan to acquire Fitbit (FIT) for USD 2.1bln reportedly stoked fresh fear on Capitol Hill. Iberiabank (IBKC) and First Horizon (FHN) announced the two are to combine in an all stock merger of equals, under First Horizon’s name.

* EARNINGS: Sprint (S) traded ~1% lower after it reported a loss per share of USD 0.07, deeper than the street consensus for a loss of USD 0.02. Revenue also fell short, printing USD 7.8bln (Exp. 8.17bln). It also noted it expects the deal with T-Mobile (TMUS) to close in early 2020, who also traded lower on Monday. Bausch Health (BHC) traded higher on revenue beats and an increase in its FY revenue view, albeit in line with expectations. Sysco (SYY) traded marginally lower; EPS beat expectations by USD 0.02 and revenue’s missed by USD 200mln. Under Armour (UAA) also reported figures although it was largely overlooked given the recent federal investigation into the company. Nonetheless, it reported EPS beats and revenue came in line with street estimates

* WTI (Z9) SETTLED USD 0.34 HIGHER AT USD 56.54/BBL; BRENT (F0) SETTLED USD 0.44 HIGHER AT USD 62.13/BBL: Crude markets bounced higher as the temperamental beast, that is US-China trade sentiment, began the week on the hopeful side. Optimistic comments from US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross saw equity indices reach new highs, something that energy traders took their cues from. Saudi Arabia announced it would be boosting its OSPs for December, further indication of a tight physical market, Citigroup analysts note; the bank also see the tape action as a “buy the news” reaction to the recovery in Saudi’s production in October pushing back on the narrative of a capped oil market. Elsewhere, Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh expects further OPEC cuts to be agreed at the 5th/6th December OPEC meeting, adding that the group and its allies are already discussing the possibility of deeper cuts, too. The latest expectations for US energy inventories see crude stocks building 2.7mln bbls, whilst the the products are both seen drawing, distillates by 0.6mln bbls and gasoline by 1.7mln bbls.

* T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 14 TICKS LOWER AT 129-18+: The TPLEX bear steepened on Monday following the positive risk sentiment, in addition to a stronger dollar and a large slate of issuance seeing investors pare back their debt holdings. US Commerce Secretary Ross gave promising comments on the US-China and EU auto-tariff fronts, reducing haven demand. Additionally, participants are facing a large amount of debt issuance, both from corporates and sovereigns, with the Treasury refunding auctions in the 3-year, 10-year and 30-year scheduled this week, and the ramp-up in corporate supply, where ten IG issuers came to the dollar market on Monday. Treasuries headed lower throughout the day, catching steam from some block sales - 20k in the TYZ9 and 8k in the USZ9 – and by settlement yields were approximately 6bps higher at the long end, with the 2-year higher by just half of that.

* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction USD 84bln in a new 3-year (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a new 10-year (USD 27bln, Wednesday) and a new 30-year (USD 19bln, Thursday). According to UBS, at next week's mid-month settlement, around USD 89bln of cash flows come due (excluding SOMA holdings, but including around USD 61bln of redemptions and around USD 28bln of coupons will fall due).

* 3-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen's analysts say the 3-year auction has set up, from a RV perspective, and is trading cheap in both asset swap and on the curve versus 2s and 5s notes. Additionally, on an outright basis, SG believes the sector looks cheap given that the current 3s WI is trading above the stop-out rate of the last three auctions. SocGen says that with the Treasury yields near the higher-end of the recent range, and a lack of clear catalysts for a sustained rise in yields from here, it expects buyers of Treasuries to materialise. But SocGen does state, however, that with relatively high dealer holdings in the front part of the curve, demand for the paper will depend on foreigners and investment funds. Overall, the bank says it is positive on the auction.

* FX WRAP: DXY traded firmer today with durable goods and NY ISM failing to provide any impetus to the buck, however the positive China trade rhetoric saw outflows of both JPY and CHF, likely leading to Monday’s bid in the Dollar index which breached the 200dma (97.465) to the upside from morning lows at 97.164, to see highs of 97.569 towards the tail end of the session. GBP traded on the backfoot to start the week, likely driven by USD strength, paring back some of last week’s gains, however the latest ICM poll put the Conservatives and Labour party differential at 7pts, narrower than the latest YouGov poll which had them at a 12pt gap, and Brexit Party’s Nigel Farage confirmed he is to contest 600 seats at this General Election as UK PM Johnson rejected his leave alliance, both potentially adding uncertainty to the conservatives hopes of reaching a majority government; Cable gradually lost ground through session heading back towards the 1.29 handle, where there is chunky option expiry at tomorrow. EUR held a similar story to Sterling where EURGBP traded relatively flat, but EURUSD traded lower on the dollar strength. The single currency shrugged off this mornings final Markit Manufacturing PMI data which ticked up to 45.9 from the 45.7, although IHS did note the report signalled a sustained weakness in output, new orders and purchasing, while job shedding accelerated to sharpest since start of 2013. Havens traded weaker today on positive trade updates from both China and the EU, USDJPY traded within the 50 and 200dma, which is 107.73 and 109.2 respectively, with participants eyeing these figures on any further risk updates. XAU remained above the 1500 level, falling from highs of 1514 to lows of 1504; CHF also lost ground against the Buck, Sterling and Euro. In EMFX, ZAR was a clear outperformer on its relief rally following days of weakness last week on its budget and utility concerns, pricing in an expected downgrade in South Africa’s outlook to negative, which subsequentially happened, although it did affirm the nation at Baa3, avoiding junk status. TRY underperformed its EM peers on further concerns as it announced it is looking to purchase a second Russian S-400 missile system, a move unlikely to please the US. Turkey’s inflation came in softer than expected, much to the CBRT’s delight, as it looks to normalise its economy by getting inflation back to its 5% target. MXN & BRL also weaker today likely driven by USD strength, with the former unreactive to Banxico’s Deputy Governor Guzman comments, who stated he forecasts Mexico's economy to recover gradually in 2020, core inflation to continue to fall in the coming months, adding the bank forecasts general and core inflation will converge to its 3% target in H2 20.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar claws back post-NFP losses, but Rand bucks the trend
content:
USD

The Greenback has been grinding higher almost across the board, with the DXY initially finding some support after holding above 97.000 in wake of Friday’s US jobs data and then gathering more recovery momentum when major currency counterparts retreated or extended losses. The index is currently just shy of 97.400 within a 97.427-164 range having digested slightly weaker than forecast factory orders and dovish commentary from 2020 Fed voter Kashkari.

JPY/CHF/GBP/EUR

The G10 laggards amidst heightened risk appetite on the back of bullish US payrolls tallies, more optimism surrounding Phase 1 of the US-China trade accord and hopes that Washington will push back or even pull pending EU, Japanese and SK auto tariffs. Usd/Jpy has rebounded from circa 108.20 to 108.60 or so, while Usd/Chf is meandering between 0.9854-90 and Eur/Chf is hovering above 1.1000. Elsewhere, Sterling remains anxious and prone to pre-UK GE jitters as Parliament votes for a new HoC Speaker and polls indicate that the opposition Labour Party is closing the gap to PM Johnson’s Tories. Cable is only just keeping afloat on the 1.2900 handle and the Pound containing losses vs the Euro ahead of 0.8650 as the single currency gleans a degree of comfort from marginally firmer than preliminary French, German and pan Eurozone manufacturing PMIs plus a more pronounced bounce in Sentix economic sentiment, with Eur/Usd underpinned between 1.1144-75 parameters.

NZD/CAD/AUD

Not quite zeroes from heroes, but the non-US Dollars lost impetus over the course of Monday’s session, and the Kiwi and Aussie especially after headlines broke revealing that India would not be adding its signature to the RCEP deal even though Australia’s Trade Minister believed that the nation would keep dialogue going. Nzd/Usd has retreated to sub-0.6420 from around 0.6465 and Aud/Usd to 0.6900 vs 0.6925 at best, with the latter also treading cautiously into the RBA policy meeting, while Usd/Cad continues to straddle 1.3150.

EM 

A lively start to the week for the likes of the Rand and Lira, with the former sharply outperforming and extending relied gains following Friday’s ratings review by Moody’s that refrained from cutting more than SA’s outlook. Conversely, the latter only managed a fleeting upturn when Turkish inflation data showed a further downturn towards target on the prospect of more CBRT easing and investor jitters about US/international relations given plans for a 2nd delivery of the Russian S-400 missile system, as media outlets suggest President Erdogan’s US visit remains uncertain. Usd/Zar now eyeing 14.7300 to the downside whereas Usd/Try currently nestles near 5.7300.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt idles, while Dollar inches higher
content: No early US data, but a bit more downside in bonds led by US Treasuries and more long end underperformance ahead of this week’s supply and non-manufacturing surveys. Conversely, some  bullish global trade sentiment has dissipated with the news that India has opted not to sign the RCEP, and this has given the DXY a lift via a retreat in the Aussie and Kiwi especially as the index nudges above 97.360, Aud/Usd pulls back further towards 0.6900 and Nzd/Usd touches 0.6425 vs 0.6465 at best overnight.

content:
• Does not want to rule out negative rates in the future; notes it is not his forecast, but something he does not want to rule out as a tool in the future
  • Fed does not know where neutral rate exactly is, but Kashkari thinks rates are around neutral and somewhat accommodative
  • Repeats his view that largest US banks needs more capital
  • Kashkari does not know if Fed is done cutting rates, notes incoming data is coming in well
  • Says it is hard to disentagle whether invetors are repricing lower rates or reaching for yield
  • Says wage growth net of inflation is now positive, which is a very positive thing

Iranian Oil Minister says OPEC and allies are already discussing the possibility of deeper production cuts at its 5th/6th December meetings, reported via Argus Media
US National Security Advisor O'Brien says we're close to a Phase 1 agreement with China

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 4th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets kick-started the week on the front-foot following a strong performance from Wall St., Japan was away on holiday
  • SCMP opinion piece noted that China might make further compromises, but the Phase 1 deal does not provide any incentive for a more comprehensive agreement
  • US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested the US may not need to impose auto tariffs later this month
  • In FX, DXY is firmer, GBP, EUR, CAD, JPY and CHF are softer, ZAR outperforms in the EM space
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Factory Orders, ECB’s Lagarde & Fed’s Daly
  • As a reminder, US Daylight Saving time ended on Sunday, hence the London to New York time gap has returned to 5 hours

TRADE

White House Trade Adviser Navarro that the sides had good talks, while he also suggested the trade deal with China will require 3 phases. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said they are very far along in Phase 1 of the US-China trade deal. Ross separately commented that they had positive conversations with Europe, Japan and South Korea, while he suggested they may not need to impose auto tariffs later this month and that talks with companies about their capital investment plans may help avert tariffs. (Newswires)

An SCMP opinion piece noted that China might make further compromises, such as reducing tariffs on imports, removing some non-tariff barriers, strengthening IP protection and further opening its markets to avert a full-blown trade war. However, the article noted that the Phase 1 deal does not provide any incentive for a more comprehensive agreement. (SCMP)

US President Trump floated the idea of Iowa as the replacement location to hold the signing of the phase 1 of US-China trade agreement. (Newswires)

Chinese Foreign Ministry confirmed that Chinese President Xi and US President Trump have been in touch via various means. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets kick-started the week on the front-foot as the region took impetus from the record highs on Wall St. last Friday following a better than expected Non-Farm Payrolls report and constructive call between top US-China trade negotiators in which progress was said to be made in a variety of areas. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was lifted by outperformance in the mining related stocks due to the trade optimism and after the recent rally in oil prices, but with gains in the index limited by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after Big 4 bank Westpac reported a decline in its FY profit. Hang Seng (+1.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) were also positive with the trade optimism turned up a notch after the recent top-level call, with even White House Trade Adviser and China-hawk Navarro noting the sides had good discussions and US President Trump also floated Iowa as a location for the signing of a phase 1 deal. Furthermore, strength in oil names contributed to the outperformance in Hong Kong, and Japanese markets remained closed today for Culture Day.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position, but will conduct MLF operations tomorrow (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0382 vs. Exp. 7.0361 (Prev. 7.0437)

 

US

US President Trump agreed to be questioned under oath by lawyers for a former Apprentice contestant who accused him of sexual assault. (SMH)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Head of Iran's Energy Authority says operation of 30 new centrifuges is underway, adding "We didn't intend to take these steps, but Washington's wrong policies pushed us to do so", reported via Al Jazeera. (Twitter/Al Jazeera)

North Korea and US working level talks could be held in mid-November/December, Yonhap citing South Korea's spy agency. (Newswires)

Reports via China People’s Daily, the communist party’s mouthpiece noted that government employees’ careers are at stake as it flagged intervention in senior appointments. (Newswires)

Turkey is evaluating a Russian offer for fighter jets and the second delivery of Russian S-400 missile system is planned for 2020 but could be delayed due to technology sharing and production talksaccording to the Head of Turkish Defence Industry Directorate. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

Following on from Friday’s post NFP/encouraging trade rhetoric rally, major European bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.9%) are again on the front foot, with further trade optimism the major tailwind. US Commerce Secretary Ross, over the weekend signalled optimistic China developments whilst noting that US may not need to impose auto tariffs later this month on the EU, Japan and South Korea, following positive conversations with these countries. DAX and Euro Stoxx indices are at fresh YTD highs, with the latter at its highest levels since early 2018. As expected, European auto names, including Fiat Chrysler (+4.0%), Peugeot (+4.9%), Daimler (+2.2%) and Volkswagen (+2.5%) are driving gains amid Ross’ comments. More broadly, sector performance is reflective of the market’s risk-on sentiment; Materials (+1.6%), Consumer Discretionary (+1.2%), Tech (+1.1%), Energy (+1.7%) and Financials (+1.6%) are all on the performing well, with the latter two aided by higher yields and crude prices from Friday’s late-doors rally. Meanwhile, the more defensive Utilities (+0.1%), Consumer Staples (Unch.) and Health Care (+0.5%) sectors are laggards. In terms of specific movers; strong earnings from Ryanair (+6.6%), Siemens Healthineers (+7.0%) and Telefonica Deutschland (+1.6%) has seen their respective stock prices advance. Wirecard (+3.7%) trades higher with the prospect of EUR 200mln in additional share buybacks providing some reprieve from the recent FT-induced declines. Finally, UK gambling stocks fell sharply (William Hill -6.9%, GVC -10%) amid pre-market reports via The Guardian that UK MPs are demanding an overhaul of gambling laws which would see online casinos subject to the a maximum stakes limit similar to the GBP 2 imposed on fixed-odds betting terminals.

 

UK/EU

UK Brexit Party Leader Farage said he won’t stand as a PM candidate in the upcoming general election on December 12th. (BBC/FT)

UK Election Polling: - YouGov poll (30th October – 1st November) shows Conservatives with a 12 point lead over labour vs. Prev. 15 point lead (29th – 30th October). The poll notes that Labour gained 6 points in the 30th October – 1st November polling period while Conservatives gained 3; hence, their lead is narrowing. Liberal Democrats on 16% (-3) for this period. (YouGov/Times)

Spanish Election Polling:

- Three polls indicate a new stalemate in Spain, no party securing a majority in the November 10th election. (Newswires)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Oct) 45.9 vs. Exp. 45.7 (Prev. 45.7) (Newswires) - German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI (Oct) 42.1 vs. Exp. 41.9 (Prev. 41.9) - French Markit Manufacturing PMI (Oct) 50.7 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 50.5) IHS said “goods producing sector is on course to act as a severe drag on GDP again in the fourth quarter” (IHS Markit) 

UK Markit/CIPS Construction PMI (Oct) 44.2 vs. Exp. 44.0 (Prev. 43.3) (Newswires)

SNB President Jordan reiterated that he sees further room to cut rates and further monetary policy loosening may become necessary under certain circumstances. Jordan also reiterated that the CHF is still highly valued. (NZZ am Sonntag) For reference, the SNB will conduct its next monetary policy review on December 12th. 

 

FX

NZD/AUD/ZAR - The Kiwi is head and shoulders above its G10 counterparts in wake of news that NZ and China will enhance their FTA, with Nzd/Usd extending gains through 0.6450 at one stage even though the latest NZ Treasury report paints a rather bleak picture of the domestic economy as Q2 GDP was weaker than expected and business activity remained depressed during the 3 months to September. However, cross-currents also favoured the Kiwi as Aud/Nzd retreated through 1.0750 and the Aussie lost traction vs its US rival on the 0.6900 handle following disappointing retail sales data on the eve of the RBA’s policy meeting – full preview available via the Research Suite. Elsewhere, the Rand is breathing a big sigh of relief after Moody’s SA ratings review on Friday as the agency resisted any temptation to go beyond the widely anticipated outlook downgrade to negative. Usd/Zar has reversed further from recent highs in response and back below the psychological 15.0000 level to test bids/support at 14.7500.

CHF/JPY - The safe-havens have receded in line with risk-on sentiment prompted by the hefty US payroll beats and rising global trade optimism amidst latest positive updates on US-China Phase 1 alongside talks between the US, EU, Japan and South Korea that could culminate in auto tariffs being rolled over or even removed altogether. The Franc is also digesting even more dovish remarks than normal from SNB chief Jordan and latest weekly Swiss sight deposits showing a hefty rise in domestic bank accounts, as Usd/Chf hovers above 0.9875 and Eur/Chf over 1.1025, while the Yen and crosses are also elevated, with Usd/Jpy eyeing 108.50.

CAD/GBP/EUR - All softer vs the Greenback as the DXY holds above 97.000 and Friday’s 97.107 post-NFP low, as the Loonie continues to reflect on the BoC’s rather concerned outlook and pivots 1.3150, while Cable strives to keep its head above 1.2900 ahead of the UK election and the Pound lags against a relatively resilient Euro after some signs of stabilisation in the core and pan Eurozone manufacturing PMIs. Note also, Sentix sentiment improved substantially and Eur/Usd may be benefiting from expiry hedging given 1 bn running off between 1.1155-60.

EM - Choppy trade in Usd/Try within 5.7075-6800 parameters after another slowdown in Turkish CPI and reports that the second batch of S-400 missiles from Russia may be delayed, with the Lira testing 200 DMA resistance, but not quite breaching the technical marker.

Moody’s affirmed South Africa at BAA3; Outlook cut to Negative from Stable. (Newswires)

 

FIXED INCOME

Some respite and decoupling from stocks that remain on an upward trajectory, with Bunds and Gilts paring a chunk of their losses from 170.98 and 131.87 intraday lows to trade considerably closer to earlier Eurex and Liffe peaks. Short covering clearly contributed to the relatively strong recovery and perhaps technical buying or cash related support as 10-year yields defended -35 bp and 70 bp respectively. However, USTs remain soft and the curve steeper post-NFP and in advance of more US releases ahead of Fed’s Daly, with new ECB President Lagarde filling the void in between.

 

COMMODITIES 

Crude markets are firmer on the first trading session of the week following overnight consolidation from Friday’s late-door gains, with impetus derived from the overall risk sentiment and in wake of of comments from the Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh who expects further cuts to be agreed at the 5th/6th December OPEC meeting (in-fitting with some of the recent sources reports ahead of the meeting, although the magnitude of the touted cuts is unknown). WTI Dec’ 19 futures have moved above last Friday’s USD 56.43/bbl high, as has Brent Jan’ 20 futures, which also eclipsed the USD 62.00/bbl level. Elsewhere, COT data released last Friday showed that speculators increased their net long in ICE Brent by 45.6k lots over the last reporting week, leaving them with a net long of 253,999 lots as of last Tuesday. “This is the largest weekly increase since early September, and also takes the net spec position back to levels seen in September” notes ING, who point out that “the increase was predominantly driven by fresh longs, rather than shorts coming in to cover.” Turning to metals; gold prices are subdued, despite the risk on moves being seen across equities and bonds. Copper meanwhile is similarly uneventful – CFTC data from last Friday revealed that speculators have increased gross longs by 11,514 lots over the week, and covered 11,949 shorts, amid recent gains in the markets risk tone.

Saudi Arabia have confirmed that Saudi Aramco is to be publicly floated, currently no indication on the timing, price or magnitude of the IPO. Reports note scepticism that Aramco will achieve its USD 2trl valuation, likely to be closer to USD 1.5trl. Stake offered could be between 1-3% valued at USD 15-60bln. (Times/Newswires)

Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh expects further cuts to be agreed at the 5th/6th December OPEC meeting. (Newswires)

subject: 285k passenger cars were re-registrated in Germany, up 12.7% y/y, according to KBA

Gilts and Short Sterling futures conceding ground as risk appetite picks up
content: In keeping with core counterparts, UK debt and STIR contracts have been unable to withstand the overall upbeat risk tone that started with better than expected US jobs data on Friday (headline numbers) and has been supplemented by more positive global trade vibes, as the US and China continue to cross Ts and dot Is on Phase 1, while pending EU, Japanese and SK auto tariffs may also be averted following positive talks according to US Commerce Secretary Ross. Looking at early Liffe price action, Gilts attempted to regroup alongside Bunds but only managed to rebound 8 ticks from initial levels before succumbing to more pronounced selling and hitting a deeper 131.87 low vs their previous 132.30 close. However, the 10 year benchmarks have subsequently reclaimed big figure status, tentatively, while the 3 month strip is also trying to pare losses from -3.5 ticks at worst ahead of the upcoming construction PMI.

subject: Head of Turkish Defence Industry Directorate says the second delivery of Russian S-400 missile system is planned for 2020 but could be delayed due to technology sharing and production talks

Norges Bank Governor Olsen notes of the NOK weakness to "surprisingly low levels", citing investors' seeking safe haven FX such as CHF and USD, adds another explanation could be that there is less of an oil industry boom vs. previous years
Turkey is evaluating a Russian offer for fighter jets, according to the Head of Turkish Defence Industry Directorate
analysis_details: • This follows US expelling Turkey from the F-35 fighter jet programme amid Turkish purchases of the S-400 missile defence system which is subject to CAATSA sanctions under a bill passed by the US House later October

North Korea and US working level talks could be held in mid-November/December, Yonhap citing South Korea's spy agency

European equity movers this morning: Siemens Heathineers (SHL GY) +6.5%, RyanAir (RYA LN) +4.2%, Wirecard (WDI GY) +2.7%; British American Tobacco (BATS LN) -1.0%, Icade (ICAD FP) -2.3%, Vopak (VPK NA) -2.5%
Norges Bank's Olsen reiterates guidance from the prior meeting, that policy rate will likely remain at the 1.50% mark for the upcoming period
Bunds: probing below pre-US payroll lows
content: The 10 year German benchmark just slipped through last Thursday’s 171.17 intraday low having failed to sustain or build on modest opening gains in relatively low-key turnover at the start of a new week due to the absence of those Japanese participants commemorating Culture Day. However, Bunds are holding in above 171.00 within a 171.47-15 range awaiting the return of EU cash bourses and the delayed Eurozone manufacturing PMIs due to All Saints Day on November 1 that arrive ahead of November’s Sentix survey. Note also, new ECB President Lagarde makes her inaugural speech later today and will obviously garner attention as she takes the reins from Draghi and inherits September’s multi-pronged stimulus package.

BMW (BMW GY) - October US sales +7.5% Y/Y at 27.8k units. (Newswires)

Additionally, DBRS Morningstar has places the two Co’s under review, positive implications after the merger announcement. (Newswires)

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

4th November 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets kick-started the week on the front-foot as the region took impetus from the record highs on Wall St. last Friday following a better than expected Non-Farm Payrolls report and constructive call between top US-China trade negotiators in which progress was said to be made in a variety of areas. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was lifted by outperformance in the mining related stocks due to the trade optimism and after the recent rally in oil prices, but with gains in the index limited by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after Big 4 bank Westpac reported a decline in its FY profit. Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) were also positive with the trade optimism turned up a notch after the recent top-level call, with even White House Trade Adviser and China-hawk Navarro noting the sides had good discussions and US President Trump also floated Iowa as a location for the signing of a phase 1 deal. Furthermore, strength in oil names contributed to the outperformance in Hong Kong, and Japanese markets remained closed today for Culture Day.

FTSE 100

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) - Co. is said to be in discussions to purchase factory in north eastern France back from Acara. (Newswires)

Ryanair (RYA LN) – Co. H1 net EUR 1.15bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.15bln Y/Y, revenue EUR 5.39bln vs. Prev. EUR 4.84bln Y/Y, Co. narrows FY net forecast to EUR 800mln-900mln from EUR 750mln-950mln and says outlook for the remainder of the year remains cautious. (Newswires)

Just Eat (JE/ LN) – Co. has warned that a digital services tax would cost the Co. GBP 7mln/year. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Daily Mail (DMGT LN) – Co. are reportedly progressing towards a takeover of the i Newspaper, sources note an agreement is on the table but the timetable has taken longer than what was anticipated. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Regulators are pressuring Co. CEO Sewing to not hold dual roles in the bank. Separately, reports note the Co. are to pass negative interest rates on to its large corporate customers and wealth customers; sparing the majority of retail clients., according to sources (FT/Newswires)

Wirecard (WDI GY) – Co. is to implement a share buyback programme of up to EUR 200mln; Co. notes the programme may be suspended and then resumed at any point. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Siemens Healthineers (SHL GY) – Co. Q4 adj. net EUR 791mln vs. Exp. EUR 770mln, rev. EUR 4.10bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.00bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Sources report that analysis of the Boeing (BA) 737 Max has led to an investigation onto the 737 NG (Next Generation), investigation is precautionary with officials from the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) and Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) reportedly involved. (Times)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Auto Names – US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested the US may not need to impose auto tariffs later this month and that talks with companies about their capital investment plans may help avert tariffs. (Newswires)

Oil Names – Saudi Arabia have confirmed that Saudi Aramco is to be publicly floated, currently no indication on the timing, price or magnitude of the IPO. Reports note scepticism that Aramco will achieve its USD 2trl valuation, likely to be closer to USD 1.5trl. Stake offered could be between 1-3% valued at USD 15-60bln. (Times/Newswires)

Vopak (VPK NA) – Co. Q3 adj. EBIT EUR 132.6mln vs. Prev. EUR 116.0mln Y/Y, rev/. EUR 312.4mln vs. Prev. EUR 311.4mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

FIAT (FCA IM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC.

INTESA SANPAOLO (ISP IM) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC.

SMI

subject: Three polls indicate a new stalemate in Spain, no party securing a majority in the November 10th election
RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 4th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets kick-started the week on the front-foot following a strong performance from Wall St., Japan was away on holiday
  • US Commerce Secretary Ross said they are very far along in Phase 1 of the US-China trade deal, whilst USTR Lighthizer and WH Trade Adviser Navarro highlighted constructive talks with China
  • SCMP opinion piece noted that China might make further compromises, but the Phase 1 deal does not provide any incentive for a more comprehensive agreement
  • US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested the US may not need to impose auto tariffs later this month
  • In FX, DXY was uneventful, EUR/USD and GBP/USD were little changed, USD/JPY was kept afloat by the positive risk tone
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Manufacturing PMI (Final); UK Construction PMI; US Factory Orders, ECB’s Lagarde & Fed’s Daly
  • As a reminder, US Daylight Saving time ended on Sunday, hence the London to New York time gap has returned to 5 hours

TRADE

USTR Lighthizer said the US and China had a constructive call on Friday and made progress in a variety of areas, while he added discussions are to continue at deputy level and that they are in process of resolving outstanding issues. In related news, there were also comments from White House Trade Adviser Navarro that the sides had good talks, while he also suggested the trade deal with China will require 3 phases. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said they are very far along in Phase 1 of the US-China trade deal. Ross separately commented that they had positive conversations with Europe, Japan and South Korea, while he suggested they may not need to impose auto tariffs later this month and that talks with companies about their capital investment plans may help avert tariffs. (Newswires)

China's MOFCOM said US-China talks achieved a consensus in principle and we're constructive, while the sides discussed the next step in trade consultations. (Newswires)

An SCMP opinion piece noted that China might make further compromises, such as reducing tariffs on imports, removing some non-tariff barriers, strengthening IP protection and further opening its markets to avert a full-blown trade war. However, the article noted that the Phase 1 deal does not provide any incentive for a more comprehensive agreement. (SCMP)

US officials stated they are disappointed by the WTO decision that ruled in favour of China and approved USD 3.6bln worth of sanctions on the US, although they see no impact of the decision on ongoing trade talks. (Newswires)

US President Trump floated the idea of Iowa as the replacement location to hold the signing of the phase 1 of US-China trade agreement. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets kick-started the week on the front-foot as the region took impetus from the record highs on Wall St. last Friday following a better than expected Non-Farm Payrolls report and constructive call between top US-China trade negotiators in which progress was said to be made in a variety of areas. ASX 200 (+0.3%) was lifted by outperformance in the mining related stocks due to the trade optimism and after the recent rally in oil prices, but with gains in the index limited by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after Big 4 bank Westpac reported a decline in its FY profit. Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) were also positive with the trade optimism turned up a notch after the recent top-level call, with even White House Trade Adviser and China-hawk Navarro noting the sides had good discussions and US President Trump also floated Iowa as a location for the signing of a phase 1 deal. Furthermore, strength in oil names contributed to the outperformance in Hong Kong, and Japanese markets remained closed today for Culture Day.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position, but will conduct MLF operations tomorrow (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0382 vs. Exp. 7.0361 (Prev. 7.0437)

 

UK/EU

UK Brexit Party Leader Farage said he won’t stand as a PM candidate in the upcoming general election on December 12th. (BBC/FT)

UK Election Polling: - YouGov poll (30th October – 1st November) shows Conservatives with a 12 point lead over labour vs. Prev. 15 point lead (29th – 30th October). The poll notes that Labour gained 6 points in the 30th October – 1st November polling period while Conservatives gained 3; hence, their lead is narrowing. Liberal Democrats on 16% (-3) for this period. (YouGov/Times)

UK Lloyds Business Barometer (Oct) 6 (Prev. 2). (Newswires)

SNB President Jordan reiterated that he sees further room to cut rates and further monetary policy loosening may become necessary under certain circumstances. Jordan also reiterated that the CHF is still highly valued. (NZZ am Sonntag) For reference, the SNB will conduct its next monetary policy review on December 12th. 

 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was uneventful which is archetypal of the post-FOMC lull and alongside a similar humdrum tone in its major counterparts with EUR/USD and GBP/USD little changed at the 1.1100 and 1.2900 handles respectively. Furthermore, the Brexit related headlines have all but died out with attention for GBP now centred on next month’s election and the power broking attempts, although UK PM Johnson has rejected Brexit Party Leader Farage's offer of forming a Leave alliance despite the latter planning to contest every seat if they cannot form a pact. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were kept afloat by the positive risk tone but with gains capped amid the lack of Japanese participants, while antipodeans also benefitted from the risk appetite coupled with a stronger CNY post-fix, although AUD lagged its trans-Tasman counterpart following a pullback in AUD/NZD from resistance around 1.0750 and after weaker than expected Retail Sales data.

Australian Retail Sales (Sep) M/M 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Australian Retail Trade (Q3) Q/Q -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)

Moody’s affirmed South Africa at BAA3; Outlook cut to Negative from Stable. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which oil prices took a breather from Friday’s rally in which the energy complex was underpinned by the stronger than expected US jobs numbers and US-China trade optimism. Furthermore, a continued decline in the latest Baker Hughes rig count added to the bullish catalyst for prices, although the rally has since lost some steam with prices marginally pulling back to below the USD 56.00/bbl level. Gold prices were flat amid a similar uneventful session for the greenback, while copper prices only mildly benefitted from the broad positive risk tone. 

Saudi Arabia have confirmed that Saudi Aramco is to be publicly floated, currently no indication on the timing, price or magnitude of the IPO. Reports note scepticism that Aramco will achieve its USD 2trl valuation, likely to be closer to USD 1.5trl. Stake offered could be between 1-3% valued at USD 15-60bln. (Times/Newswires)

Baker Hughes US rig count (Nov 1) oil rigs -5 at 691, nat gas rigs -3 at 130, total rigs -8 at 822. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Reports via China People’s Daily, the communist party’s mouthpiece noted that government employees’ careers are at stake as it flagged intervention in senior appointments. (Newswires)

Venezuela and El Salvador have expelled each other’s diplomats. (Newswires)

 

US

Treasuries pared gains and yields were higher across the curve by around 3bps, though major curve spreads were little changed at settlement, after the US employment situation report surprised to the upside, although action was still tentative ahead of the manufacturing ISM, which missed expectations, though rose versus the prior. Additionally, commentary around US/China trade has been constructive, giving hopes that the Phase One deal can be signed, while there was not much in the Fed-speak for the FI bulls, with officials generally encouraged by the state of the economy, while noting familiar risks. Combined, it might that pricing for December rate cuts lightened, with money markets implying around 12.5% chance of a cut, versus around 22% at the close of business on Thursday. T-note futures (Z9) settled 9 ticks lower at 130-00+.

Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said Fed policy is unlikely to change unless there is a change in outlook and suggested a shift this year has provided significant support, while he also stated that global risks still exist and that the full impact of Fed policy shift is yet to be felt. (Newswires)

Fed's Quarles (Voter, Neutral) said US economy is doing well and that he is optimistic about the outlook as well as the longer-term potential of the US economy, while he added that a particular source of strength has been the labour market. (Newswires)

US President Trump agreed to be questioned under oath by lawyers for a former Apprentice contestant who accused him of sexual assault. (SMH)

content:
Asia equity markets kick-start the week on the front-foot as the region takes impetus from the fresh record levels on Wall St. following a better than expected Non-Farm Payrolls report and constructive call between top US-China trade negotiators in which progress was said to be made in a variety of areas. ASX 200 (+0.3%) is lifted by outperformance in the mining related stocks due to the trade optimism and after the recent rally in oil prices, but with gains in the index limited by weakness in the largest weighted financials sector after Big 4 bank Westpac reported a decline in its FY profits. Hang Seng (+1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) are also positive with the trade optimism turned up a notch after the recent top-level call with even White House Trade Adviser and China-hawk Navarro noting that the sides had good talks, and US President Trump also suggested Iowa as a potential location for the signing of the phase 1 deal. Furthermore, strength in oil names contribute to the outperformance in Hong Kong although gains in the mainland are somewhat restricted by further PBoC liquidity inaction, while Japanese markets remained closed today for Culture Day.

In FX markets, the DXY is uneventful which is archetypal of the post-FOMC lull and alongside a similar humdrum tone in its major counterparts with EUR/USD and GBP/USD little changed at the 1.1100 and 1.2900 handles respectively.  Furthermore, the Brexit related headlines have all but died out with attention for GBP now centred on next month’s election and the power broking attempts, although UK PM Johnson has rejected Brexit Party Leader Farage's offer of forming a Leave alliance despite the latter planning to contest every seat if they cannot form a pact in the next 2 weeks. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are kept afloat by the positive risk tone but with gains capped amid the lack of Japanese participants, while antipodeans also benefit from the risk appetite coupled with a stronger CNY post-fix although AUD lags its trans-Tasman counterpart following a pullback in AUD/NZD from resistance around 1.0750 and after weaker than expected Retail Sales data.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: US & China top trade negotiators had a constructive call on Friday and were said to have made progress in a variety of areas
content:
China Aoyuan Property (3883 HK) - Co. October contracted sales rose 55% Y/Y to CNY 10.0bln. (Newswires)

South Shore Holdings (577 HK) - Co. unit to sell shares and loan of Uni-Dragon for total consideration of HKD 750mln. (Newswires)

Springland International (1700 HK) - Co. receives offer to go private for HKD 2.30/Shr. (Newswires)

Zijin Mining (2899 HK) - Co. purchases Timok Copper and Gold Mine for USD 240mln. (Newswires)

Financials - China is expected to ask most online lenders to exit the business. (Newswires)

Tobacco - China tobacco regulator reportedly urges e-commerce platforms and businesses to shut down e-cigarette online shops. (Newswires)

 

Trade

US President Trump floated the idea of Iowa as the replacement location to hold the signing of the phase 1 of US-China trade agreement. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US and China are working hard to conclude a trade deal, while the two sides continue to make progress on a Phase 1 pact and are in talks for an alternative to the cancelled Chile meeting. (Newswires)

USTR Lighthizer said the US and China had a constructive call on Friday and made progress in a variety of areas, while he added discussions are to continue at deputy level and that they are in process of resolving outstanding issues. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross stated US is pretty comfortable phase 1 trade deal with China is in good shape. (Fox)

NEC Director Kudlow said US negotiators are very optimistic on a US-China deal and that Phase One deal is not yet completed but the agricultural, currency and financial services chapters are nearly done. Kudlow added that enormous progress is being made on IP theft issues but it will probably slip into Phase 2 of deal, while he suggested the threat of December tariffs is still on the table until Phase One is signed and that Trump hinted he may be willing to look at those tariffs if Phase One is completed. Furthermore, Kudlow stated the China trade deal is further than it was in May which was the last time it was near to completion. (Newswires)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro said the sides had good talks on Friday, while he also suggested the trade deal with China will require 3 phases. (Newswires)

China's MOFCOM said US-China talks achieved a consensus in principle and we're constructive, while the sides discussed the next step in trade consultations. (Newswires)

China has issued draft foreign investment law rules where China will allow foreign funded firms to raise funds through stock and bond issuances in China and overseas. In related news, China will further open up its market for foreign enterprises as Beijing and Washington are poised to sign an interim trade agreement, although the pace of reform will not be led by the US according to reports citing a China diplomatic observer. (Newswires/SCMP)

The WTO have ruled in favour of China in a dispute and approved USD 3.6bln worth of sanctions on the US, while US officials later said they are disappointed by the WTO decision although they see no impact of the decision on ongoing trade talks. (Newswires)

 

Other News 

PBoC is to improve financial and macroeconomic adjustments, while it is to also quicken the pace for supply side structural reforms as part of the 2020 targets. (Newswires) PBoC stated that it conducted CNY 200bln in MLF, offered CNY 60.1bln in SLF and conducted CNY 75bln of pledged supply lending during October. (Newswires)

Over 33% of China provinces have failed to reach growth targets so far this year with the traditionally poorer areas showing most signs of difficulties. (SCMP)

 

Protests - Hong Kong protesters clashed with police over the weekend in which the police fired tear gas to try and break up protests, while another incident involved a knife attack. (Newswires) 

 

Data Recap 

  • Hong Kong Retail Sales Value (Sep) Y/Y -18.3% vs. Exp. -25.6% (Prev. -23.0%). (Newswires)
  • Hong Kong Retail Sales Volume (Sep) Y/Y -20.4% vs. Exp. -28.5% (Prev. -25.3%)
